Award.AwardTitle: Rural Integrated STEM Education: Middle and High School Teacher Pathways Developed Through a Regional Alliance

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
With support from the NSF Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program, this project aims to serve the national interest in high quality STEM teaching by increasing the number of talented and adaptive STEM teachers in rural California. This project will build capacity to educate STEM teachers by developing a plan to recruit, prepare, and support undergraduate STEM students from two-year and four-year colleges to teach in rural, high-need middle and high schools. By transforming the early experiences of future teachers, the project aims to develop highly qualified STEM educators capable of investing in the next generation of scientists in rural districts and communities. The project partners will develop a plan for two-year teacher preparation pathways that focus on inquiry experiences and STEM research in the first two years of college.

The project will establish a regional alliance between three post-secondary Hispanic Serving Institutions (HSIs) and the County Office of Education, which represents 24 school districts in California's Central Coast region. This alliance will collaboratively develop early-access STEM teacher pathways. The HSIs (California State University Monterey Bay, Hartnell College, and Monterey Peninsula College) will plan how to integrate evidence-based components into early STEM teacher pathways. These components include active learning and culturally responsive pedagogy, with the expectation that the additions will contribute to STEM teacher diversity. The Next Generation Science Standards Regional Collaborative Teacher Network, coordinated by the County Office of Education, will provide prospective teachers with access to an inclusive STEM community of practice, which includes in-service teachers with expertise in STEM-teaching best practices. The project action plan will identify steps to develop early STEM inquiry, teaching, and mentored research opportunities. The project has the potential to develop a model for broadening the pool of STEM students who enter teacher education programs at the California Community College System (113 colleges) and the California State University System (23 universities). As a result, this project may provide a blueprint for an expanded STEM teacher preparation pipeline, thus helping to address rural STEM teacher shortages and broaden the pool of highly-qualified STEM teachers. The NSF Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program supports talented STEM undergraduate majors and professionals to become K-12 mathematics and science teachers in high-need school districts and in-service teachers to become STEM master teachers. It also supports research on the persistence, retention, and effectiveness of K-12 teachers in high-need school districts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Rural Integrated STEM Education (RISE) partners want to prepare highly qualified Science, Technology, Engineering and Math (STEM) teachers. The RISE partners also want to understand how teachers effectively facilitate students learning STEM and becoming high qualified STEM professionals. To achieve both of these goals, three California Central Coast Hispanic Serving Institutions (HSIs) and a County Office of Education: California State University Monterey Bay (CSUMB), Hartnell College (HC), Monterey Peninsula College (MPC), and the Monterey County Office of Education (MCOE), partnered to plan and develop pivotal, evidence-based components of STEM Teacher Pathways. Our collaboration is driven by an urgent need to implement systemic changes that would remove barriers to early STEM teacher pathway recruitment. We want to streamline how we recruit, prepare, and support highly qualified students to become STEM teachers, and to meet the challenge of diversifying the pool of STEM teachers in response to the needs of local rural school districts. 

The key outcomes of this one year capacity building project were:

  1. The development of a recruitment framework designed to attract a large and diverse pool of undergraduate STEM majors who might not otherwise have considered a career as a K-12 STEM teacher. The framework includes evidence-based best practices for recruiting students earlier into the STEM teacher pathway. 

  2. The design of STEM Teaching Pathways at each participating institution. The STEM teacher preparation outcome integrates planning for inquiry-based learning, developing conceptual knowledge, and increased implementation of science and engineering practices as advocated by the Next Generation Science Standards. 

  3. The creation of an alliance with clear roles and responsibilities for each institution in the project in anticipation of a Track 1 program. A crucial consideration for our collaboration was the design and implementation of structures necessary to support students' development of STEM identity and self-efficacy as highly qualified STEM teachers. 

We envision community college and lower division STEM students who benefit from the outcomes of RISE saying: "As a scientist and future STEM teacher, I see myself among innovative STEM teachers integrated into our rural communities to address the K-12 educational needs of our students." Long term goals four our collaboration include increased persistence and retention of STEM majors, particularly underrepresented minority students; increased transfer of community college students into STEM teacher pathways; and increased graduation of STEM majors pursuing a teaching credential.

Based on findings from the Noyce capacity building grant, we plan to prepare a Track 1 proposal to provide Noyce Scholars with the relevant cultural competence, pedagogical knowledge, experiences, and disposition to be successful K-12 teachers in high-need local educational agencies. To support STEM content mastery and familiarize students with the process of inquiry, students need opportunities to acquire, practice, and master prioritized skills of teaching STEM with support from co-teaching partners, academic coaches, and university faculty. This is especially important for underrepresented minority students who might not have experienced inquiry instruction as students in K-12 settings, but who would benefit from developing mastery of science practices, essential to ensuring that quality teachers emerge from the credential program. Extending student teaching and research experiences into community college and lower-division courses will address these issues by supporting students' development of STEM learning, research, and pedagogy practices. 

More broadly, outcomes from the capacity building project contribute to the larger discussion, particularly within the California Community College and California State University systems, on how to broaden the applicant pool of highly qualified STEM teachers, as well as expand and refine recruitment activities for URM students. Although STEM jobs have relatively high earnings compared with many non-STEM jobs, one potential barrier for those wishing to enter the STEM workforce is the level of educational attainment required for such positions. STEM education in rural America where agriculture, manufacturing, and energy jobs require an increasing understanding of STEM, is one example of the strategic value of STEM education. The design of programs like RISE that build early STEM teacher capacity and institutional alliances to improve K-12 student achievement and engagement will change the demographics and impact of STEM teachers in California thus transforming the STEM workforce. Rural communities will benefit from highly qualified STEM teachers. Exponential change in STEM K-12 student outcomes begins with transforming STEM Teacher Pathways through our collaboration to emphasize early recruitment, preparation, and support.
